Do you know how to implement Test Driven Development? I'll tell you how I do it.

It is not easy, it took me several months to get good at it. It's hard to explain, a lot of concepts are involved. It's even harder to explain it in detail in a single post. This is the first part of a series of posts about the practice. I'll start with the basics, then I'll move to more advanced topics. 

Do you want to know more? Just let me know in the comments.

I’m constantly learning new things. One of them is TDD (Test-driven Development). I’ve already heard about it but only recently I began to put into practice. It’s not easy at all. ‍TDD requires constant control, a lot of discipline and focus, and it’s not easy to implement. But if you want to achieve high quality, you have to implement it in your production code.

Here’s how I correctly implemented this.

Before I started testing, I wrote thousands of lines of code and hundreds of bugs. Now I write 100 lines of code and 0 bug.

Why?

 Because I learned and implemented TDD: Test-driven development.

Every time I write some code, I start by thinking about the test that will be used to verify it is working correctly. I do it when I write a function, a class or a library. And then I start writing the test, which will take 10-15 minutes. And then the code for the test takes about 10 minutes. And then I write the code for the function that will be tested by the test. And then I write the code for the function that will call the function that will be tested by the test. And then I can realize that this is stupid, so I delete everything. And then I start again with just one test and one function to call.

It's easy to say: test, test and test. It's not so easy to do it, especially when you have a lot of code to test. But if you want to implement TDD, you have to learn how to use the tools. I've been studying it for a few years now and I've tried many tools. So here are my recommendations:

TDD is a great way to incrementally build your code while adding tests to test and validate your code. I use it every day. But it can be hard to implement if you don’t know where to start. So I’m sharing my approach on how to implement TDD:
1. Set a goal
2. Write a test
3. Code the feature
4. Run the test 
5. Refactor
6. Repeat! Let me know how it works for you!

Here's how: 
1 - Find your audience 
2 - Find content that addresses your audience 
3 - Engage them with this content

Talk about yourself, not just about your company. Share your stories, your lessons learned. Be transparent and authentic. Show your audience you are not just another salesperson, but a real person with whom they can connect and interact.
